headline.main: U.S. Envoy to Pakistan Thrust Into Limelight

lead_paragraph: Like so many other Americans, Wendy J. Chamberlin, the United States ambassador to Pakistan, found herself in a changed world on a late-summer day 10 weeks ago -- a world that transformed her, in an instant, from envoy to a country in a diplomatic deep freeze to occupant of one of America's most important ambassadorial postings. In the early evening of Sept. 11, as perfect a day in Islamabad as in New York, Ms. Chamberlin was walking from her office in the sprawling embassy complex to her residence. As she entered the marbled hallway, one of her two daughters, Chynna, 14, called from the television room upstairs, ''Mummy, come here!''
abstract: Sept 11 terrorist attacks transformed Wendy J Chamberlin's post as ambassador to Pakistan into one of United States's key diplomatic jobs; she has helped enlist Pakistan's support for American military operations in Afghanistan and reward Pakistan with economic aid package; has remained highly visible despite hostility of Islamic militants who back Taliban; she comments, interview; table of biographical data; photo (M)
